did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Melvan Tibbetts papers contain letters to and from Melvan Tibbetts, a Union soldier from Maine who served along the Texas coast during the American Civil War.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Melvan Tibbetts (1845-1927), son of Elisha and Christiana Tibbetts of Exeter, Maine, was one of seven children. He enlisted as a Union soldier during the American Civil War. It is worth noting that the 1860 census listed his age as 15, meaning he would be 16 years old at the start of the Civil War, but his enlistment papers claim he was 18 years old. Regardless, he enlisted as a private on December 17, 1861, into Company H, 15th Maine Infantry.

The 15th Maine was sent first to occupy newly captured New Orleans, Louisiana, in 1862. In 1863, the unit was posted to various places along the Texas coast, as part of the 13th Corps, 4th Division. The unit participated in the disastrous Red River Campaign in 1864. After the campaign, the unit was reassigned back East.
Melvan Tibbetts survived the war. He passed away on November 1, 1927.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the letters of Melvan Tibbets who was a Union soldier during the Civil War. Tibbets's letters provide information about food prices in South Texas, weather conditions, illnesses and medical treatment, and military skirmishes. The last letter relates to the withdrawal of his company to Berwick, Louisiana, in March 1864.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Melvan Tibbetts papers contain one series: I. Correspondence. The letters are arranged chronologically in a single folder.
